1/4x lambda( wave length of that frequency).
Thickness=1/4-1/2 lambda interfer due to refraction. The back plane of the film, dependant on the n- index number is responsible for amplifying the light. If the back plane of the film is close to one then there will be less light bounce. Also the n- index is responsible for the angle of refraction, exiting the film.
The holes are 1/4- lambda apart, causing amplification of the harmonic multiple of the fundamental node- 1/4xlambda x N, Where N => infinity as the amplitude goes to zero( basically 2- colours are amplified together)- producing a different color.
The angle of color view is caused be n 1x Sin( theta)= n2 x sin( Theta2). Air has an n value of 1 and glass has the value of 1.5, so you can use this to determine the width of those holes separation by the two amplified colors hitting your eye.
In all , Polaroid work in the similar way except the thickness is 1/2 x lambda

the spacing between the dots is crucial. They work by changing light reflected from the surface, and it depends on the angle of the incoming light, so different spacings work best at different angles. But still, to manipulate visible light, you need to be in the range of its wavelength for it to work.

However, larger spacings work for larger wavelengths, like radar or microwave. and for smaller wavelengths, crystal structures can create this effect, which is the basis of x-ray crystallography.

some light always reflects and some goes through, but if the reflected light from the front surface destructively interferes with light reflected from the back surface then you see no reflected green light. This happens when the thickness of the film is half the wavelength.

CYAN is a blue/green color.
MAGENTA is a kind of rosy-purple.

Generally you want the film to be half the wavelength of light that gets cancelled out because the wave is inverted at the front interface upon reflection. The holes are trickier to explain but they do perforate the material.

Depth has to be half of the wavelength,because the light travels twice through it. Once inbound, and once again outbound after the reflection at the bottom of the hole. That causes the light to be shifted by 1 wavelength but due to the reflection, it is phase shifted by π. So if you take the one bouncing on the surface with the one bouncing on the bottom, they add up, cancelling each other out.
